review_title: Unsettling but necessary; Surefire nominations for Viola Davis & Octavia Spencer
review_detailed_main:
The Help is at once a joy to watch for its absorbing yet haunting story and for the superior acting by Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer. On the other hand, it is nauseating at times to suffer through the scenes of outright cruelty perpetrated by the white women of the south in the early 1960s. It is one thing to read about Jim Crow in a book or listen to an old person nowadays discussing what it was like, but to see reenactments of just how dehumanizing and vindictive the times were is just unsettling. This is an important story, fictional yes, but representative of a time and a place which reminds the audience just how ashamed we should be at aspects of our past.

A few decades ago in the south, it was commonplace for a white family to employ a black maid. Maid is an all encompassing term for house cleaner, cook, nanny, grocery shopper, butler, and every other menial task you could think of. They potty trained the toddlers, read them stories, and pretty much raised the children instead of their mothers who were enjoying that afternoon's bridge party. This particular story takes place in Jackson, MS and focuses on three main characters.

'Skeeter' (Emma Stone) has just graduated from Ole Miss, one of her only clique to do so, and returned home to get her foot in the door at the local paper. It appears she went to school for an education rather than to husband hunt which sets her apart from her friends. She wants to be a writer but does not have the experience to get hired on by a true publishing firm. What really separate Skeeter though is that she has a much more enlightened view on race relations. This is odd. Where did this character pick up the notion that perhaps certain things should not just be left alone and separate but equal is anything but? Skeeter's mother (Alison Janney) does not display any sentiment towards her maid and Ole Miss was not widely acknowledged to be a bastion of forward and progressive thinking thought in 1963. It is strange that Skeeter is of such a different mold than the rest, but there would be no plot if she was not.

Illicitly, Skeeter starts to interview the black maids of the town. She spends most of her time with Aibileen (Viola Davis) and Minnie (Octavia Spencer). These two maids share with Skeeter their horror stories of maltreatment, child neglect, and every other behind the curtain story their employer would not want anyone else to know. Skeeter is combining all of the maids' stories into a book to tell the rest of the country what is going on down south from the maids' perspective this time.

I have a hunch that come awards time, there will be a Best Actress nomination for Viola Davis and a supporting nomination for Octavia Spencer. The film is strongest when they are on screen. Viola showed traces of her character in 2008's Doubt and this is Octavia's first true starring role. When the film flips back and focuses on the white women for a time, especially when it shows Skeeter trying to find a boyfriend or argue with her mother, the atmosphere loses its tension and the pacing slows until it gets back on track with the maids. This film is truly unsettling at times, but well worth the audience's discomfort to show them a time and a place not very long ago which was not just immoral, but malicious.

I can only echo the other reviews already written about this outstanding movie.

The performances are incredible, especially Viola Davis, who shines in her role.

Credit also goes to Tate Taylor, who wrote the screenplay and directed this wonderful film.

The story is poignant, but also funny, and describes the racism that took place in the South during the Sixties.

I can only highly recommend THE HELP.

All in all, I recommend the movie.

review_title: Shallow Treatment of a Complex Subject with Strong Performances

review_detailed_main:
The Help depicts a brutally honest time in American history where whites were superior and the blacks were inferior. Right around the Jim Crow era where the typical white family lived in a sizable house, with kids, and some of the richer families had a black maid to look after the kid(s). The black maid was forced to drop everything in her home life to cater to the, sometimes cruel, white family. They were expected to be fast, friendly, and honest. They were the help.

The film is based on the novel by Kathryn Stockett, who was raised by a black woman because her mother was working a lot of the time. The Help shows how some maids became the mother of the child, and at some point, they were even called "mom." Reminds me of a Hank Williams song My Son Called Another Man Daddy. Only difference is the mothers in this didn't seem to mind the maid being called the mother. They were too busy to notice.

The story is about two African American maids named Aibileen (Davis), a middle-aged woman who has been taking care of white kids for nearly her entire life and just lost her son. And Minny (Spencer), the mouth of the two with an abusive husband, but a great sense of humor. She provides much of the comic relief to this story.

Jackson, Mississippi, the town of the film, bribes blacks of their freedom of speech and their rights. They literally have no say in anything. A woman was beaten for going down to vote, and some have even been killed. Brave aspiring-journalist Eugenia "Skeeter" Phelan (Stone) has just been hired by the Jackson Journal newspaper, and is set to write an article, which turns into a novel, with the help serving as the voice of the book. Skeeter wants people to know that these humans have their own lives, but spend their time taking care of other children, being forced to work under whatever circumstances and limitations they have, while being the subject to verbal abuse by their employers and racial segregation in the household.

To the whites, the blacks might as well be mannequins that can do work. The don't care about their feelings or their opinions just as long as they work efficiently and clean up after themselves. The characters, on the other hand, are introduced at hyper-speed, but the story cleans up after itself and takes time to introduce them one by one, giving proper and worthy character development to each.

Emma Stone is charismatic, while the maids are hilarious in portions of the film as well. Even in the films darkest hour, it manages to keep a sunny disposition and not get bogged down by painful scenes and a depressing feel. Sure the end credits to leave room for some tears, but scattered scenes across the movie brought the audience I was accompanied with to cheers, screams, laughter, clapping, and sadness, it's all realistic and honest.

To wrap up the summer, The Help is a gem. A break from all the comedy, romance, and talking animals. It's sure to be overlooked by a younger audience, when it shouldn't. This is an important film, that needs to be seen by many. It's good things like this come out, reminding the public of the past. Those who don't know history are likely to repeat it, and we need films like The Help to prevent that. No one likes repetition. Especially in reality.

review_title: Good cast in typical feel-good story
review_detailed_main:
It's hard to fault a movie like this, when it seems perfectly aware of what kind of movie it wants to be, and does a great job achieving its goal. Basically it is a typical feel-good story, set in a small town with obvious racial tension. The story is at times predictable - though that often feels irrelevant for movies like this. I agree that it is too bad that there still are so many movies about this kind of stories being made, this movie handles it quite nicely.

The highlight of this movie is the cast. There are some great performances in this movie from actors I was completely unfamiliar with. Mostly the "helps" are doing a great job, enhanced by convincing (to me) costume- and set-design.

I wish that this movie would have had higher ambitions, gone longer in exploring the good side of "evil" people and the bad side of the good - making the characters all more human. I guess it would have been a different movie, but definitely a more interesting one.

When I was in high school, my Speech Teacher/Forensics Team Coach gave me this book to look for monologues. He told me that it was a great read, too! However, I didn't want to read it or find a monologue within it. I let my sister borrow it, and I returned it back to him. My sister loved the book! Then, they made the movie... Boy, I kicked myself for not reading it or finding a monologue.

I thought that this movie was supposed to be set in the American South in the 1960s. But really it seems to be set in an alternate universe where nothing makes any sense. How is it that the protagonist has grown up in the same society as all the other (racist) women, yet has a completely modern, 21st century viewpoint? Things just don't work that way.

Racism in the movie was portrayed as a pervasive but ultimately trivial issue. The movie reduced racism to the petty meanness of society ladies, largely skirting issues such as sexual harassment and mob violence. We have one scene of police brutality and another scene with a vague reference to a shooting, but these events seem to come out of nowhere and vanish without a trace afterward. What happens to the woman who is arrested, after the arrest? We never find out.

Another thing that bothered me about this movie was how the black women are portrayed as largely feeble and helpless until the white women ("Skeeter" and Celia, in particular) teach them to stand up for themselves. This was partly due to the fact that the movie was, first and foremost, about Eugenia's coming-of-age experience and not about "the help" at all. But still, it was dissatisfying.

In addition to these issues, the characterization was rather poor and the cinematography was nothing special.

I wish I were more well-versed in history, so I really lay into this movie properly. But even as my uninformed self, I could tell that there were many things wrong with this movie. Not recommended.

review_title: Amazing female ensemble delivers perfect mixture of humor and drama
review_detailed_main:
Late-summer Civil Rights dramas don't come around much. In fact, late-summer dramas don't come around much period, but "The Help" has just the right pinches of humor and bright colors to keep it from becoming a weighty affair more suited for the winter awards contenders. Don't assume, however, that come the turn of seasons that anyone will have forgotten "The Help" come awards time.

Tate Taylor adapts and directs Kathryn Stockett's best-selling novel about African-American maids living in Jackson, Miss. in the Jim Crow era. Viola Davis plays Aibileen, a woman who has been raising the children of wealthy Southern white families for decades. When college grad Eugenia "Skeeter" Phelan (Emma Stone) returns home with aspirations of becoming a journalist, she tries to convince Aibileen and fellow maid Minnie (Octavia Spencer) to tell their stories in hopes of getting their perspective heard. Although the women fear their identities being discovered, the prejudicial attitudes of Miss Hilly Holbrook (Bryce Dallas Howard) and her initiative to force homes with maids to provide a separate bathroom for The Help provokes them to courageously speak up.

"The Help" puts out a massive ensemble effort glowing with talent. Never has a female- dominated cast of this size given such strong performances across the board. Aibileen provides the narrative voice, but Skeeter, Minnie and others each get their stories told in full depth and the supporting roles from the likes of Allison Janney as Skeeter's mother and Sissy Spacek as Hilly's mother are priceless.

If a standout has to be chosen for Oscar consideration, it has to be Davis. There's that constant look in her eyes suggesting that she's always carrying every single thing her character has ever been through into every scene. She's penetratingly real; she is everyone's mother. She also brings the film's wide range of emotions, though the comedy would be Spencer's forte.

Spencer, a long-time small-role character actor, follows Taylor from his first feature-length film "Pretty Ugly People." She makes the film a true delight with a hold-nothing-back attitude. Minnie embodies some racial stereotypes, but the script gives her such incredible depth that we associate those things with who she truly is, not as a vehicle for humor.

Perhaps — oddly enough — too many characters feel multi-dimensional and "The Help" lacks a true focus for a film running nearly two and a half hours, but the acting is so sharp at all levels that it never feels boring or hollow. The characters and the many situations and problems they deal with feel unmistakably real, namely because those problems break the mold for Southern Civil Rights drama.

The film avoids being another example of how terrible things once were and how poorly blacks were treated. It asks us to feel sorry for everyone, not just the African-American characters and scratch our heads at how life was ever like that anywhere in this country. Ultimately, "The Help" tells a story of courage in one of its unlikeliest forms — telling the truth, making sure all side are heard. It uses such a diverse tool set of characters to get that point across.

Taylor's much more concerned about working with these actresses to create compelling portraits of characters and relationships in a place and time full of unique issues than he is with creating gripping drama. Considering the film is no less poignant and maybe all the more likable for it, he made the right choice.

~Steven C

review_title: I hope The Help won't be missed by the Oscars
A very sincere, hilarious, and emotionally powerful movie lies within The Help.
review_detailed_main:
I took the time recently to see a wonderful ensemble drama called The Help, a film based on the novel by Kathryn Stockett.

The film centers around two main story lines in Jackson, Mississippi in the 1960's: First of which are the African-American housemaids working for white families. This includes Aibileen (Played by Viola Davis), a woman whose spent her whole life as a maid, not to mention having lost her only son, but still stays true to her beliefs.

The other main narrative is that of Eugenia Phelan, aka. Skeeter (Played by Emma Stone), a woman recently hired by the local Jackson newspaper, who wants to have interviews from the point of view of the housemaids, even though they could face jail time for doing so. Never the less, Aibileen accepts, and Skeeter's project starts to form.

Some would probably accuse The Help's screenplay of feeling emotionally forced, but what writer/director Tate Taylor constructs is actually a more honest, emotionally involving project. The themes of racial segregation give the film a dramatic edge, but it's also brimming with irresistible humor. What could have been a sappy melodrama actually feels more sincere.

Same goes for the cast, who could have been butchered if not for casting directors Kerry Barden and Paul Schnee just nailing it. It's hard to pick a standout, but it's worth noting the individuals for their work.

Jessica Chastain performs with equal hilarity and grace. Viola Davis, the closest thing to a standout, gives off understated, but powerful emotion. Bryce Dallas Howard, normally a very sweet soul, is evil enough to get your nostrils flaring. Allison Janney gives off a sarcastic, but also sympathetic vibe. Sissy Spacek tickles in her small supporting role. Octavia Spencer excels with a no bull crap attitude. And Emma Stone, with her charm and believability, works wonders as Skeeter.

I must also make note of the technical crew of the film. Sharen Davis' costume define an extra depth of personality, and Thomas Newman supplies another emotionally potent orchestral score. Oh, and I almost forgot about editor Hughes Winborne. At a little over two hours and fifteen minutes long, the movie just flies by.

As it is, there are many parts that feel like they're in the film because they're in the book but weren't as fully fleshed out in the movie as I imagine they were in the novel. An entire storyline involving Jessica Chastain as a helpless housewife who turns to her black maid to help her is welcome because it gives Chastain a chance to deliver a winning and immensely likable performance, but I'm not sure what it really had to do with the rest of the movie around it. The character played by Allison Janney doesn't make much sense at all. Representative of a certain kind of white person who's basically well meaning but allows peer pressure to turn her eyes away from the injustices of segregation, her character is first portrayed as a foolish and vain woman with whom we're supposed to be disgusted and then turns on a dime to become a champion for her daughter, played as appealingly as always by Emma Stone, when her daughter writes an expose of white oppression from the point of view of the black household staffs. And don't even get me started on the character played by Bryce Dallas Howard, an unlikable actress anyway who's given a gross caricature to play, so vile but ultimately so juvenile that she threatens to undermine the entire point of the movie -- if all racists were as silly and as easy to dismiss as her, all of our race problems would be solved.

predictability saved by the power of female acting chops, especially Viola Davis
review_detailed_main:
I may be giving this a higher rating that it deserves; it's a predictably plotted story and you know how a lot of it's going to go, what lessons may be learned by and to whom and so on. But like The King's Speech, it's nice to see an Oscar-bait(ish) movie that has strong performances (with one exception, which I'll get to momentarily) and on its own terms is pretty good. Not very good, or great, and The Help may be overrated, but it carries a strong message and I liked seeing these actors as these characters together, for the most part.

As a story surrounding the Noble White Savior(TM) it surprised me how the cast was handled very evenly (Viola Davis got a best actress, not supporting, nomination for good reason and probably should've won all things considered). I thought it would be the Emma Stone show, with her as the Mississippi writer who works for a local paper but gets inspired by what she sees with the local maids working for generations (basically linked by blood and heritage and all to slavery) and gets a book deal about what it's like for 'the Help' to work and live. I though that all these other women (this is very much a woman-centric movie as well, which is commendable, albeit directed by a man) as small side characters. Not really the case, which helps since if you get tired of seeing one character it'll soon flip over to another.

I heard from a few friends in the years before seeing this that Octavia Spencer's Minny was over the top, playing up the "mmHMM" Big Black Lady stereotype and got an undeserved Oscar. I thought she was fine, and more than that really, and got to portray a fully fleshed out character, and especially put against two very different white ladies - Bryce Dallas Howard's Hilly and Jessica Chastain's Celia, both she works for at separate times - we see how she can be your best friend or your worst enemy (if you push her far enough and hard for a long time like Hilly).

If I had any problem it was with Howard, though that may be more in the writing; she's the one clear antagonist, but by and large because whenever she's on screen, even if she's sitting peacefully and only saying a little bit, there's a feeling like 'oh wow, what's she about to say now or put on that ugly-mean thing that has the guise of 'Southern Gentility'. But with what little she's given I found Howard more caricature than character, while Chastain, also seemingly not given quite a lot with a white-trash lady like Celia, she was a lot more fun and interesting and had real dynamics to play with (and tragedy as well). Perhaps I'm wrong and Hilly was fun to play as well, but I'm not sure I saw it.

The heart of the movie though is Davis, and without her I probably wouldn't recommend the movie as much as I do. Yes, the great Allison Janney, in just a handful of scenes, does wonders as she always does as Stone's mother, and Emma Stone's Skeeter herself is really good as well (a few moments that should be especially tear-jerkery, like with a revelation surrounding a formerly employed maid who raised Skeeter, feel earned just by how much the actresses commit and don't let a lot of falsehood enter their performances).

But I just felt the movie take it up a notch or two with Davis there, and I'm sure (first-time!) director Tate Taylor knew that as well. Just simple scenes showing Aibileen playing with the little white baby girl, or protecting her under a mattress during a tornado, there's just so much warmth to play with but also a lot of horror from that period of time in history, and she finds it all. Even (maybe especially) when she says little and is just standing there, exhausted, sad, trying to hide her deep-seated rage, Davis reminds us not just about how good she can act but about the constant, just understood horrors of the black experience at that time and place.

In short, The Help is highly watchable as an actor's movie, and compensates for a little over-length (I'm not sure where, but it could've lost ten minutes somewhere I bet) and with things moving at a pace where you know how things will end up with this book coming out and who may or may not get it. Needless to say the ending also caught me off guard for how emotional it got, also genuinely and to a point where I was sold by what the actors were doing but also the deeper implications of what this ending meant for everyone involved.

review_title: A few moments of lumpy throat emotion but no Cry Freedom.
review_detailed_main:
I whizzed through the novel by Kathryn Stockett. It's an easy read and a couple of evenings took care of it without any great aching of the brain. It's no Tolstoy (it's not even as demanding as a Stephen King) but certainly more entertaining. The trouble is, it's popular. Very popular.

And then came this; the popular, the very popular, film adaptation.

I rail against the hysteria that follows a new fad, particularly films and books. I have a real aversion to being told what I must like and how much I should like it. I resisted Harry Potter for a good few years until my nieces insisted I read it to them. And then? Actually I though thought the first book was bland and distinctly average and, had it not been for the gentle urging of a respected friend, I would have stopped at book one. The Help, apparently unable to speak for itself, is another work being touted by the world's media as a great, a must-see, an Oscar certainty It's another cinematic bandwagon laden with unthinking passengers who are enjoying the mild hysteria they're experiencing and justifying by the ever-growing mountain of awards that is burying the film.

For those who walk around with their fingers in their ears, it serves up the story of a privileged white girl who, in a bid to launch her writing career, hits upon the idea of writing a book from the point of view of the slaves, sorry, the help, who keep her home, and that of all the homes of the rich white folk in the deep south of America, going. It's onto a winner from the outset and has no work to do because, let's face it, we all know that racism is evil and, for the most part, the white folk have learned that much of what they did was despicable.

I entered the cinema with an expectation, and perhaps even a determined hope, if I'm honest, that the film would fail for me and I'd leave unmoved and with thoughts overloaded with disdain to hurl into this post. I left with a slightly modified view and an emotional tickling i.e. not as severe as a bashing.

I strongly suspect The Help is 2012's Driving Miss Daisy, to wit, we'll shower it with accolades now but in a few years we'll realize we've been hoodwinked and, actually, it's not very good. Yes, it serves up a few good moments of lumpy throat emotion but it wasn't sufficient to make me blub. Yes, it has something to say but it lacks the impact of, say, a Cry Freedom in its day. This is a classic case of preaching to the converted and allowing us all to feel good about ourselves because we agree with the message. I'm guessing it won't reach many die-hard KKK members and therefore will have no impact on the persisting issues.

But there are plenty of high points, not least of all Jessica Chastain who is rapidly becoming one of my FAIDs (Five Allowed In Dreamtime – more on that in a later post) along with her unofficial sibling (is it only me who sees it?), Kelly Reilly. Her turn as Celia Foote is huggably engaging but, alas, she plays little more than light relief to the weightier roles Aibileen, Skeeter and Hilly. Viola Davis is sincere in her portrayal of Aibileen, the matriarch of her community, and the focal point for those handing out gongs but for me this is an ensemble piece and I don't think any actor stands out as more deserving than another. Although it may earn gold, it doesn't have gold written across it and I'll hark back to my comment about Driving Miss Daisy.

Emma Stone is not the Skeeter I imagined as I read the book and she's coasting here, well below the quality and impact she previously promised in Easy A and even Zombieland. Alison Janney, yet again, enhances the group effort and Sissy Spacey has fun in a pantomime cameo.

Much of the story is abbreviated for pace but the biggest cause of irritation comes at the end credits in the form of Mary J. Blige's horribly jarring song, The Living Proof, that is saccharine pulp and both too modern and too twee for a film that, despite it's lightweight failings, is a film worth spending a tenner and a couple of hours on.

It's good. It's very enjoyable. It'll make you feel good about yourself for being on the side of justice. But it's a little like eating an entire loaf of white Mother's Pride toast with marmalade; it goes down perfectly but sometime after the event you'll realize there was no substance to it and you require something more, well, real. This year it earns four stars from me but I expect, if you ask me to watch it again in five years, I'll settle on three.

"The Help" is a film set in the 1960s just as the Civil Rights movement is taking off. Skeeter (Emma Stone) returns to her home town in Mississippi after college, desiring to become a writer. Shocked by the way some of the women treat their Afro-American maids, Skeeter decides to write a book from the viewpoint of the maids. Her family had a maid who basically raised her, Constantine (Cicely Tyson), but she's left the family, and Skeeter is unable to find out anything about why or what happened to her.

The first housekeeper to open up is Aibileen (Viola Davis) and eventually more women join in. And it's quite a story they have to tell. Little do they know, they are on the cusp of the Civil Rights movement. Change is coming.

The cast for this film is magnificent -- Bryce Dallas Howard is the nasty Hilly, Octavia Jackson plays a maid, Milly, who goes to work for Celia; Allison Janney is Skeeter's mother, Jessica Chastain is the heart-of-gold, rejected Celia, accused of breaking up a marriage. Every one of them creates a full character, and their acting is perfect. Both Howard and Stone step into a new category of acting expertise.

Cicely Tyson has a few very small scenes, and she nearly steals the film. It's her performance that will haunt you.

Also in the film are Sissy Spacek, Mary Steenburgen, Leslie Jordan, and Dana Ivey.

This film will make you laugh, make you angry, and finally make you cry. It catches the '60s atmosphere and also the varying attitudes of the southern women, many of whom are bigoted and condescending.

Unfortunately the racial problems in this country have yet to be solved. I remember one black woman and her husband going to Buffalo, New York, and being amazed that they could walk into any restaurant and not be thrown out. Another friend's father became ill while they were traveling in the south. They went to a clinic - because her father was of Sicilian descent and had been in the sun, he was cared for on the black side. Being from the north, they had no idea there was a black and white side.

When you think about how many of these people had to live their lives, the restrictions they lived under, the lack of opportunity, it's sobering.

Excellent film, thought-provoking, and highly recommended.

Over ten years later and The Help is still as touching and relevant as the day it came out. First, it should be noted that the Help is a fictional film based on Kathryn Stockett's 2009 novel by the same name. However, I don't think it makes the story any less relevant. The film follows an ambitious writer in the 1960s, who publishes a book with multiple stories of black maids' point of view on the white families for which they work, and the hardships they go through on a daily basis. While the stories are fictional, the situations feel very, and the characters are very relatable. In fact, some of these same issues, particularly the separation between the haves and have nots are still present in our society today. The cast is amazing, and there isn't a weak performance from anyone. Viola Davis, Octavia Spencer, Emma Stone, and Bryce Dallas Howard give some of their best work. Anna Camp even has a small role, and it is clear this was before she got famous. But she still plays her part excellently (there are also some really good deleted scenes with her in it on the DVD). The second thing is that this film is sometimes accused of perpetuating the idea of the white savior. To people who think that way, I would say that context is important and that the time this film takes place in, African American women didn't have the same opportunities as an upper-class white woman would have, and clearly, a movie set in 2011 would approach the subject matter differently. I will also say that there are times when people need to step in when they see inequalities in their society, and it doesn't matter what their race is as long as they are helping to create a better society for everyone. It's not a perfect film, but it's a must-watch for its subject matter alone. Because don't we all want to be told "you is kind you is smart you is important" ?

review_title: It Goes On - And On - And On
review_detailed_main:
This isn't a bad movie. It actually has a lot of good material in it. It's an interesting perspective on the civil rights movement of the 1960's and especially on race relations in the state of Mississippi. It revolves around the writing of a book by Skeeter (Emma Stone) - an aspiring author largely raised by a black maid employed by her family who decides to write about what life is like as a black domestic servant in the City of Jackson. As we watch her write, and as she manages to get more and more of the stories of the various "maids" shared with her, we see the sadness and injustice of the southern lifestyle of the era. The "maids" were only slightly better off than the slaves who had come before them - at the whim of their "employers," poorly paid and useful mainly because they allowed the women they worked for to enjoy a relative life of ease, not even having to take responsibility for the raising of their own children. There may have been a little too much caricature involved in that portrayal (although not having lived in Jackson, Mississippi in the '60's, I can't say for sure) but this certainly gives a taste of the era and the society. This isn't about marches or protests, although the killing of civil rights leader Medgar Evers earns a mention; it's a story about people and the struggles they faced overcoming a legacy of racism.

And yet, while it's worthwhile (and even manages to tell a difficult story with a fair bit of humour thrown in) it also came across to me at least as lacking a real edge or focus. It needed something more to really draw me in. The stories offered an interesting vignette of southern life, but there wasn't enough of interest to really keep me glued to the film. In fact, throughout the last 30-45 minutes, I was mostly interested in how this was going to end, and frankly every time a new scene came up the thought that went through my head was "there's more."

I appreciated it. It made a point, and of course it had the requisite heart-wrenching ending (which, for this story, was very appropriate and not at all superfluous) but it needed something more; it actually needed a lot more for my tastes (although, on the subject of tastes, the story of Minnie's chocolate pie alone makes this movie definitely worth watching!) review_title: Civil Rights with a Human Heart in an Emotionally Cathartic Film Led by the Incomparable Viola Davis
review_detailed_main:
Directed by Tate Taylor in only his second full-length effort, this 2011 period film isn't perfect, but its precarious blend of gravitas, pathos and humor tugs at the heartstrings in a way that makes the story emotionally riveting without veering into the maudlin or being condescending, no small feat considering the ongoing temptations in Tate's fully ripened screenplay. Set in his hometown of Jackson, Mississippi, in 1961 just as the civil rights movement was taking hold of the Deep South, the film benefits immeasurably from its excellent cast, in particular, a gut-wrenching performance from Viola Davis, a brilliant actress who blazed through just eight minutes of screen time in John Patrick Shanley's "Doubt". Showing more nuanced shades of her trademark stoic strength here, she serves as the film's emotional center as Aibileen, a haunted middle-aged maid who has spent most of her life raising white children and just recently lost her only son to racially motivated violence.

Based on fellow Jacksonian Kathryn Stockett's popular 2009 novel, this immensely satisfying adaptation faithfully covers most of the book's major plot points and fluidly shifts viewpoints between Aibileen; her sassy best friend Minny, who can't help but show her contempt for her racist employers; and Skeeter Phelan, a young white woman and recent college graduate who after moving back home, discovers that Constantine, the dedicated maid who helped raise her since childhood has mysteriously disappeared. The three women's stories intertwine seamlessly to explain how life in Jackson revolved around the co-existence of blacks and whites in a state of casual yet hostile intimacy. The symbol of institutionalized segregation is the bathroom, a firebrand issue led by Hilly Holbrook, the town's demonic debutante who is pushing to pass an ordinance to support her belief that all homes should have separate bathroom facilities for the "colored" help. This revelation makes Skeeter realize how deep the racial divide is in her town. Ambitious to become a serious writer, Skeeter pitches an idea to the publishing house of Harper & Row to write a book that would show her world from the black maids' perspectives, an idea fraught with danger to all who dare to participate. Spurred on by civil rights activist Medgar Evers' assassination in Jackson, the maids unify in their support of the book (a scene that reduced me to tears), and it becomes a big success but not without certain sacrifices.

Beyond Davis' sterling turn, there is an embarrassment of acting riches - Octavia Spencer's tart-tongued turn as Minny threatens to steal the picture entirely, especially in a hilariously vengeful chocolate pie scene that almost belongs in a completely different movie; an extravagantly coiffed and costumed Bryce Dallas Howard, surprisingly effective as Hilly, the most venal and unrepentant of racists; Jessica Chastain in full-blown Marilyn mode as the white-trash wife ostracized by the bridge club set; Sissy Spacek easily stealing her brief comic scenes as Hilly's dotty mother fully aware of her daughter's character shortcomings; Allison Janney as Skeeter's acidic, status-conscious mother who proves it's never too late to change your ways; Cicely Tyson lending unforced dignity and an uncanny Jane Pittman countenance to the flashback scenes of Constantine; and smoky-voiced Emma Stone, who officially graduates from comic supporting roles and truly comes into her own as Skeeter. The whole cast deserves to be remembered during awards season. Not by accident, the men are given short shrift here. A more experienced filmmaker than Taylor could have instilled a greater sense of fearlessness in the movie's approach, although at the same time, few would be as generous with such an outstanding cast. Despite some moments that border on being too broad, the film represents superior entertainment about a period of American history that needs to be remembered.

The Untold Story of African-American Maids Raising White Children in the South: The Best Film on the Subject Since "The Long Walk Home"
review_detailed_main:
In American historic culture, we often think of race relations in terms of the civil rights protest marches of the 1960's and the work of Medgar Evers and Martin Luther King Jr. Behind the scenes and for many decades prior to the legislation signed by President Johnson in 1964, African-Americans and Southern Whites interacted within a societal infrastructure which was not often discussed. African-American hired "help" often raised the white children of southern aristocratic society. Eugenia "Skeeter" Phelan is a young white woman raised by one of these African-Americans, Constantine Bates, whom she regards as the person who raised her. She decides to document the experiences of the maids when she finds out Constantine was fired by her family without her knowledge.

Aibileen Clark, played by Viola Davis in an Academy Award-caliber performance, is the first maid solicited by Skeeter. At first reluctant to share her thoughts and experiences, Clark eventually decides to reveal her story. Others follow, including Minny Jackson (Octavia Spencer) who was once in the employ of Hilly Holbrook, the most racist and insensitive of the upstart white women. As Skeeter hears their stories, she finds a recurring theme of negative attitudes exhibited by the white women toward the Help, ranging from disrespect and discourtesy to racist contempt. At one point, Hilly tries to have legislation passed to require all households with hired help to have separate bathrooms for African-Americans.

Ironically, Celia Foote, the one white woman who was formerly among the "poor white trash" treats her new employee Minnie with respect and decency. But because of her background, Celia is shunned from the women's groups. At one point, she tries to visit the local women's bridge club, but the members hide inside the house, pretending they're not there. Eventually, she learns the hard way that prejudice can cut in either direction. Her employee Minnie becomes more than just the Help but a kind of mentor.

Despite its marketing, "the Help" is not a comedy-drama. It really is a rather sobering look at stratified culture in Jackson, Mississippi in the early 1960's during the civil rights protests. The aristocratic mothers have hired African-Americans to care for their children and houses, but show little appreciation toward the people who are part of their lives. In several instances these children know the Help better than their white mothers. In a very poignant scene, a local Ladies Club made up of many of the young mothers has taken up a fund-raiser to help starving children in Africa. But they seem oblivious to the people in their own community who might benefit from their work. Even simply offering a kind word appears to be outside of their modus operandi. I guess the point is that no one in these families believes it's necessary, and so these prejudicial attitudes are passed from generation to generation. Unfortunately, when the white children become adults they don't necessarily have the same affection for those who raised them.

No question, one of the best films of 2011, with outstanding performances by all the leads and supporting cast. I believe there will be several Academy Award Nominations. While Emma Stone as Skeeter and Emma Howard as Hilly deserve high marks, Viola Davis and Cicely Tyson steal the show. Both exhibit very different persona's when they are in the midst of whites than when they are at home. This may be the best film of this subject since "the Long Walk Home".

review_detailed_main:
I enjoyed "The Help" but for all the wrong reasons. I loved the high production values, the beautiful lighting, the shots of ripe agricultural fields in the Deep South. I especially loved the exquisite, tailor-fit, vintage, early 1960s dresses worn by the white actresses. I got a huge kick out of the over-the-top performances. Bryce Dallas Howard, though a living person, is every bit the Walt Disney cartoon villainess. You love hating her. You grimace when she cackles and you cackle as she reaches her inevitable, and utterly unbelievable, nightmare, revenge-dream-fantasy downfall. Howard should have won an academy award. Viola Davis, who radiates soul and depth and can make you cry just by walking into a room, is the deep, rich heart of this otherwise silly film. Octavia Spencer is adorable. She's as big-eyed and woebegone as a DW Griffith Gish sister. I have no idea why Emma Stone is the star. She can't act much and she isn't a drop dead beauty. Maybe she knows someone.

"The Help" is about black-white relations in Mississippi in the early 1960s. Jim Crow Mississippi was a terrorist state. That sounds like an extremist statement; it is not. The Mississippi Sovereignty Commission planted spies in every nook and cranny of Mississippi life. It aided at least one assassin, Byron de la Beckwith, who murdered Medgar Evers. This deadly serious, tense, historic era is reduced, in "The Help," to a very pretty soap opera featuring magical Negroes – a term used to describe black characters in mostly white films who exist only to provide a means for the main, white character to grow.

You notice immediately in "The Help" that the white women are all slim, elegantly and flatteringly dressed, and pretty. The black women are plump, older, and plain. But, this is an uplifting film about Civil Rights, so all the black women are noble, giving, selfless, and saintly, while all, except one, of the whites are vicious, vacuous, selfish, and bad mothers. Also, all the whites are filthy rich. Was it really that way, you have to ask? No, it wasn't. Mississippi has one of the highest white poverty rates in the US. And some whites joined the Civil Rights struggle, performing the ultimate sacrifice, and giving their own lives. Still waiting for a feature film about Viola Liuzzo.

Maybe it's not such a bad thing that simplistic and overtly exploitative movies like this get made. If they interest any viewers in the Civil Rights movement, that's not a bad thing. Maybe it will inspire some to see a truly worthy film series, "Eyes on the Prize."

The whole pie-eating thing trivialized what the maids went through and how they must have retaliated at times. It was too over-the-top in the movie and too much emphasis was put on it to the detriment of other parts of the story that would have rounded it out better.

If you're on the fence on whether or not to see the movie, do yourself a favor and read the book. It might take a little longer, but it will be a more satisfying experience.

"Skeeter" was a result of such upbringing and did not become as obnoxious as her parents and their friends. The little girl featured with Viola Davis's character called her her real mother. At Monticello, a docent spoke with what I can only describe as a Black dialect. Because Blacks were kept away from education, the dialect was almost incomprehensible. review_title: A satisfying film with superb acting
review_detailed_main:
So I finally watched "The Help", a movie which, considering the precursors, has good chances of earning a considerable number of Oscar nominations next Tuesday. And it sure didn't disappoint me.

The story revolves around the society of Jackson, Mississippi, in the 60's, focusing on the relationship between the black maids and the white women they work for. There's Skeeter (Emma Stone), a modern young woman who, unlike most of her lady friends, has graduated from University and has aspirations of becoming a writer. As a result of his job as a "homemaker hints" columnist in the local paper, for which she asks maid Aibileen (Viola Davis) for help, she decides to write a book about the Help.

The film, hence, has a powerful message about tolerance and equality. I felt that, though this works well and gives the film depth, sometimes it gets a little too obvious and makes it falls into the sentimental, tear- jerking territory. It's not like it bothered me, because it didn't, but I just thought it could have been handled a little more subtly. But hey, Disney's involved in it, so what did we expect?

The strong point of the film is the female cast. The actresses are perfect in their roles and they truly shine throughout the film. Emma Stone, as Skeeter, brings really well the modernity and the wit her character requires and Bryce Dallas Howard, though a little "cartoonish" sometimes as the evil and despicable Hilly Holbrook (which is understandable) really delivers too. But I found the following three performances even better:

Viola Davis, as the suffered Aibileen, does great in the most heart- breaking scenes and shows once more what a good actress she is, after her short but top-notch role in Doubt, where she outshone everyone (even Meryl Streep!). In spite of this, I'm having a little problem about her being considered the lead for all the awards. Though she's one of the centers of the film, she is missing in a big part of it.

Secondly, we got Octavia Spencer, as the sassy Minny Jackson. It's true that hers is not a difficult role to play, but she's really really funny and one of the best parts of the film.

And last but not least, the wonderful Jessica Chastain. Her Celia Foote could have easily been played as an over-the-top, one-dimensional bimbo, but she brings a depth and humanity that make her character the most endearing and likable in the film, in my opinion. I enjoyed her scenes with Minny the best.

Overall, "The Help" is a perfectly enjoyable film, with amazing performances and an interesting storyline. It doesn't get tiresome at all, despite its considerable length, so I really recommend it. Regarding the Oscars, though, I do not think it should win best picture, but I'd be happy if one of the ladies took home the award, which seems likely.

I know I'm late to the game but, i just want to say i loved this movie. At times it was very hard to watch. I was a child in Jackson, Mississippi in the 50s and early sixties and I still remember the days of whites only here. We were not rich, very much not, but my Mom had a made I think once or twice a week and Gertrude kept us whenever Mom and Dad went out. We loved her. She told us funny stories, rocked us and tucked us in. We were always kind to her. I never knew about this side of her life ... I was a child and not aware. The stories here moved me very much and sometimes I smiled and laughed and sometimes I cried. It was sooo well done and in spite of the hardships shown here, really heart warming at times.

"The Help", critically and commercially praised as "extraordinary" and "sensational", was a film that I felt must be overrated. What a surprise to find that "The Help", written and directed by new-comer Tate Taylor, is hardly exaggerated, and happens to be THAT funny and THAT feel-good.

Emma Stone brings her classic heart and spunky pizazz to a character that, without an actors touch, could have been overtly dull. And though it is Viola Davis who appears to be getting all of the critic's love, I think that it is Octavia Spencer who really pulls her weight in the film. Not only does she consistently remain side-splitting hilarious, but she captures a passion the film is lacking in the help department. (This is no way means Davis didn't use her acting-chops with elegance, simply that she was not the break-out maid).

As Jessica Chastain's second (of many) film in 2011, she manages to still be youthfully tender and jubilant; who could have predicted this same time last year that Chastain would hypnotize audiences and command the screen? Who could have guessed that Bryce Dallas Howard would continually make a splash as the "bad" one? Certainly not me, and I'm sure not many of you either. But here I sit, and here you read: unable to help but smile thinking about "The Help" and all of the subtle and vibrant performances that litter this years only film with a predominantly female cast. A film that makes women proud to be where they are, who they are and gives us all that little bit of courage we were missing previously.

The only facet of this deliciously well-composed film that fell-flat was the "romantic-interest" of Stone's character Skeeter. It's always nice to have a good man for a strong leading-woman, but one who is so unnecessary and, frankly, boring has no place in a film as flamboyant and thought-provoking as "The Help". A fatal writing flaw that ruined the film's masterful quality and intense shining excellence.

A must see of 2011, and surefire Oscar bait.

review_title: Gets So Much Right and So Much Wrong....
review_detailed_main:
I'll give "The Help" 10 stars for the Women. Viola Davis, Octavia Spencer, Jessica Chastain, Cicely Tyson (playing old, old, old yet again) are thrilling to watch. They have the all out fierceness that makes movies like "The Help" enjoyable and seem to give them "weight". One wishes the film makers trusted these Women more and let them have more screen time. When Emma Stone's Skeeter finally gets Viola Davis' Aibileen to talk to her for a book she's writing about the experiences of black women who serve as housemaids and nannies in assorted white households in Jackson Mississippi circa 1963, Aibileen very tentatively begins by relating a story of the first child she took care of as a 14 year old in 1925. The way Davis speaks it, the story sounds fascinating and I wanted to hear all the details. But the director cuts away the scene to where Aibileen and Skeeter are done with their talk and we never hear all about Aibileen's story. The movie could have done with a lot more of the real stories about these women's lives but we only get bits and pieces. We really don't get to know a whole lot about them and that's a shame. We might think we get more but that is because these actresses are so damn good that we fill in the gaps ourselves.

I'll give the "The Help" one star for what is gets wrong and it's not the first to do so. The film once again focuses too much time on the oh-so-helpful-wizened-white person role this time played by Emma Stone as Skeeter. She's one in a long line of actors who've played this part. Coincidentally (or maybe not) Sissy Spacek (a bit horrifying here in an old lady role. She's only 62!) played this role once in a movie called "The Long Walk Home". I assume that the money behind this film felt that in order to get white audiences interested, they had to keep this legacy going. While I think it's OK to have this kind of role, the film makers once again my the role pretty much the central character but they try and circumvent this by having Viola Davis' Aibileen narrate the picture (though this narration seems to be absent throughout long stretches of the film). It's insulting to the main characters in the film ("The Help" of the film's title) and diminishes from some of the meaning the film has. The rest of the white cast ranges from barely adequate/watchable (Spacek) to eye rolling caricature (Bryce Dallas Howard's Hilly Holbrook). The least said about Howard's character the better.

I'll recommend "The Help" based solely on the African-American actresses (and Chastain as the only white character with some depth of feeling that seemed genuine). The rest is filler that we've seen before and can do without.

review_title: Surprisingly Good For What It Is.
review_detailed_main:
I am far from this films target audience. Most films that center around racial prejudice such as Crash, The Blind Side, or Remember The Titans tend to simplify the issue and tend to have the feeling of a T.V. movie or a class lesson video, so I don't usually hold them that high in regard. Which is why I was shocked at how much I ended up liking this film.

The films plot centers around an aspiring journalist (played by Emma Stone) trying to write a book of stories about the lives of black maids working for rich, white families in Jackson, Mississippi during the civil rights movement. As such, it has the common themes of family, prejudice, acceptance, and understanding seen in these sort of films. The thing that sets it apart is the story and characters are generally well written. Everyone has well defined characters, even if some of them are a bit cliché, and they all act and react the way there personalities say they would. You can actually see these people existing in the real world, which allows you to connect with them much easier. As much of a trope as the stay-at- home, airhead 50's housewife is, I find it pretty entertaining, especially when such characters are fleshed out and interact with each other.

On top of that, the film understands when to let the audience laugh. Even though it is mainly a drama, the humor in feels very genuine and constant, even if it can be a bit sit- com like at times. This is what separates it from films like Crash as it doesn't let the message drag the movie down and make it depressing. Also unlike Crash, The Help doesn't talk down to the audience. It gets it point across just through the flow of the story, without having to resort to dropping a giant anvil marked "racism is bad" on your head. It shows that there is more to racism than just hate. It can also come from societal pressure or be taught from birth. The movie respects your intelligence, and that's a rare thing to find in films these days.

The film gives you drama and a few laughs and treats its subject matter with care. The characters are well written and well acted. To top it all off, you got a soundtrack that has Johnny Cash, Bo Diddley, and even a little Bob Dylan. What's not to like. Consider this a strong recommendation.

This film tells Skeeter Phelan's efforts to write a book based on interviews and testimonies of black servants serving in the homes of wealthy white families of Mississippi. Directed by Tate Taylor (who is also responsible for screenplay, based on the Kathryn Stockett's novel), the film has the participation of Emma Stone (Skeeter), Viola Davis (the servant Aibileen), Octavia Spencer (the servant Minny) and a number of talented actresses.

This film deals with interesting questions, starting with the race issue, which is still a ghost hovering over the US, and the issue of civil rights and the rights of employer over the employee. From there, the film gives us to know moments in the life of these servants and we see that, in spite of their humility, they're essential for those families, where women have the appearance of not even knowing fry an egg. The cast fulfills its mission very well but without surprise us with supreme interpretations. The only exception is Octavia Spencer, who touches us and moves us in the role of Minny, justly deserving the single Oscar that the film won: Best Supporting Actress.

Our society often doesn't hear the voices of most humble. However, without them, society would fall like a house of cards. We all need each other. This film is about this: humble people in search of a voice, trying to tell their testimony, having right to speak, feel and live.

review_title: "The Help" addresses the heavy theme of racial segregation but the theme is superficially contextualized and the focus is wrongly in the white characters most of the times
review_detailed_main:
Based on the book "The Help" by Kathryn Stockett and written and directed by Tate Taylor in 2011, "The Help" takes place in Mississippi in the 1960s and follows the story of Skeeter (Emma Stone), a young woman who has just finished college. And dreams of being a writer. She turns the city upside down when she decides to research and interview black women who have always taken care of "Southern families". Despite the confusion caused, Skeeter gets the support of Aibileen (Viola Davis), a friend's housekeeper, who gains the trust of other women who have a lot to tell. However, relationships are forged and brotherhoods emerge amidst the need that many have to say before the changing times hit everyone.

The strong point of the film is not the denunciation of the mistreatment of blacks, nor the fight for civil rights, or even the search for female overcoming (as writers, housewives or wives). In a very intelligent way, director and screenwriter Tate Taylor does not shy away from these themes, but he does not use them as the sole motivation for the film either. Instead, the film has a lighter tone, often even comical, and seeks to bring us closer to the characters, to immerse ourselves in the adventure with them. This could be considered a form of cowardice on the part of Taylor (who is a childhood friend of the author of the eponymous bestseller), but the truth is that this decision contributes a lot to the identification and originality of the film, without preventing the important message be transmitted. It is therefore natural that the spectator becomes deeply involved with the characters and that the story starts to have an intimate relationship with us, and not just a denunciation.

From a technical point of view, The Help is impeccable: Mark Ricker's production design and Sharen Davis's costumes do an admirable job of recreating the period while effectively contrasting the spacious comforts of employers' homes with the oppressive misery of the maids' hovels, opposing, on the other hand, the sterility of the former and the pleasant family feeling awakened by the latter. In addition, the locations that reveal large properties surrounded by vast lands suggest a lifestyle closer to the slave trade period, pre-Civil War, than to a modern society about to send the first man to the Moon.

Because, as unbelievable as it may seem, it wasn't long ago that racial intolerance came to be seen as something pernicious by society - suffice it to say that, less than 30 years ago, marriage between whites and blacks was still prohibited by law in some US states. Thus, when we see a boss impolitely ordering his maid to make him a sandwich, or a mistress demonstrating repugnance at the idea of seeing her maid using her bathroom, we feel simultaneous shocks caused by the stupidity of those actions and by recognizing that, even today, there are people who see others as inferior just because of their color - and, as in the film, it is not uncommon to witness bosses who refer to their employees in a pejorative way as if these, who are beside them, were invisible or deaf.

Featuring a superb performance by Viola Davis, "The Help" is almost saved thanks to the actress's sensitivity, which displays, in small gestures and breathing changes, an infinity of complex and painful feelings - and notice how she almost gasps while gets ready to start narrating his stories to Skeeter or how his hands shake when welcoming the journalist into his home, since he had never had a white guest in his home. It is she who unnecessarily narrates the story. She is the one from whom we should hear more stories about her profession, which she has been practicing since she was 14 years old. But Tate Taylor's eagerness to return to the wealthy suburbs and show off more jokes keeps audiences from identifying even more with the character. The precipitated death of her son is the only personal fact that she fully recounts.

Moreover, the feature moderately displays the passivity of this dedicated maid, which would not be so true if played by an actress other than Davis. The expressiveness of this belatedly discovered talent makes magic with so little that is given to it. However, to realize the richness of her performance, it is enough to contrast her with the caricature created by Octavia Spencer, whose Minny oscillates between two modes, "angry" and "funny", constantly combining them to achieve a greater comic effect - and the result is that, even suffering physical abuse from her husband, the character's drama never really gains weight.

But the film's biggest problem, however, is that, although its story is essentially about the living conditions of black housemaids and these are its most interesting characters (even Minny), the film insists on investing most of its narrative in the core of white socialites and their "problems", starting with Celia (the beautiful Jessica Chastain, from "The Tree of Life"), who suffers from not being accepted by her classmates, and ending with the protagonist, Skeeter, who dreams of being a journalist and grew up thinking she was ugly and inadequate due to the pressures exerted by her mother. Incidentally, the white characters in Taylor's script are basically divided into two groups: the pure-hearted ones, who embrace the maids and treat them as equals, and the despicable villains, who do everything to humiliate them (and to make it even worse). Of course, the terrible woman played by Bryce Dallas Howard even develops a sore on her face, and it is notable that the director has restrained his own impulse to put a witch wart on his nose). The maids, on the other hand, are invariably stoic creatures and owners of ancient wisdom - and even their most reprehensible actions appear as perfectly justifiable reactions to the villainy of their employers.

As exclusionary as its real main characters (the exception is Skeeter), Tate Taylor's script is a complete contradiction, going so far as to only mention the domestic aggression experienced by Minny (Octavia Spencer), one of the maids, while the repercussions about a controversial chocolate pie served to Hilly goes on for several unnecessary minutes. These erroneous options end up making the film not become an apology, which gives blacks the space they always lacked, but an act of revenge against whites. But what is most sickening about "The Help" is how, at the end of the day, it is white people who come to the aid of poor, powerless black people, saving the day with their kindness - and, believe it or not, the simple fact that the housewife played by Jessica Chastain preparing a meal for Minny leads the latter to finally work up the courage to stand up to her husband.

Likewise, the film's discussion of racism is more about the changes experienced by the Caucasian affluent (Skeeter's mother got well all of a sudden! Oh!) than about the actual suffering of the oppressed black class, which at the very least reveals the concern filmmaker - white, of course - to the effects of it all on his fellow racers. In fact, it is unbelievable that Taylor not only wrote, but rehearsed, filmed and kept in the final editing a scene as artificial as the one that shows Skeeter's mother firing a maid who has worked in her house for 30 years just to see herself momentarily. Pressured by high society friends. But what to expect from a guy who, from the third act on, seems to simply throw any sign of subtlety in the air and decides to dedicate himself exclusively to the purpose of drawing tears from the spectator? And how he tries to do it: in a matter of minutes, we have the old scene that shows several characters getting up while offering support to someone ("I'll help!", "Me too!", "Count on me!"), another that it follows a character being applauded by dozens of people and exchanging meaningful nods with a friend; and, of course, a child crying and banging on a window glass when he sees someone leaving.

"The Help" stands out for its great interpretations. The screenplay is sometimes shallow, unable to escape the didacticism of emotion or laughter at certain times and of superficial and one-dimensional characters. It survives through the deep interpretations of the cast, aware that the secret to the film's success was to make the characters real and close to the public's daily life. Thus, even with the white bosses looking like shrews, or completely good as in the case of Celia, in an unnecessary Manichaeism between conservatives and liberals, the women (the male figure is almost non-existent) become convincing thanks to the interpreters. The screenplay, moreover, contains little-needed subplots, such as Celia Foote's pregnancy and Skeeter's relationship. They only serve to illustrate behaviors of the time (the woman who cannot give her husband a child or the independent woman pressured by her mother). Little to the possible social drama.

The problem is that "The Help" addresses the heavy theme of racial segregation in the extremely conversational Mississippi, but does not give up on being a "feel-good movie". The region was the birthplace of the Ku Klux Klan - an organization that violently persecuted blacks -, but the theme is superficially contextualized, as well as the quick references to Martin Luther King. That is, any political issue is thrown into space, even with the motto being the desire of journalist Skeeter to, for the first time, tell the story of those who were marginalized by society. The work of the cast (almost completely female), by the way, saves "The Help" from tragedy. From the top of their caricatures, they are still able to arouse viewers' empathy. The various dialogues in Taylor's script, as well as his measured direction with some rhythm, allow for such a highlight. Too bad they are all in favor of a technically well-finished work, but narratively failed, which gives a voice to those who already had it, displaying an embarrassing veiled prejudice.

review_title: This Movie was Going to Happen
review_detailed_main:
"The Help" is the type of movie that I watch only after I've answered one question to myself: "Am I ready to be angry?" I know that even if there is a happy/positive ending, at one point during the movie I am going to be profoundly angry. So I have to ask myself if I'm ready to be angry. If the answer is no, I move on. If the answer is yes, I strap in for the show.

"The Help" delivered on the anger inducing as I expected, but it delivered on being a quality movie as well, as I expected. The help in this movie were, of course, African-Americans working in service roles, but it focused on Aibileen Clark (Viola Davis) and Minny Jackson (Octavia Spencer). They, along with other housekeepers/nannies/servants were the subject of a book being written by Skeeter Phelan (Emma Stone). Her book was stories of being a servant from the perspective of the help.

The movie is based upon a book by Kathryn Stockett. It succeeds in showing the racism of Mississippi without showing lynchings, murders, or beatings. In fact, for the most part, there's not any violence at all. What we see is a more passive form of racism and oppression from the aristocratic women of Jackson, Mississippi. It came in subtler forms such as making them use separate bathrooms, treating them with disrespect and contempt, and denying them simple dignities.

Where the movie fails is putting a spotlight on its protagonist Skeeter. Her character gets a total pass because she's seen as someone who's an ally of the help, yet she also exhibits an even subtler more patronizing form of racism. Her own nanny was fired by her mother and she sheds tears because of it. She sheds those tears more for herself than for her nanny Constantine (Cicely Tyson). She'd lost her mother figure, yet that caused her to cry out, "She needs my help!" as though Constantine wouldn't be able to survive without her. Fortunately, the Constantine saga wasn't dwelled upon.

"The Help" was still a moving film that deserves the praise it's gotten. It was a slow paced, yet engaging movie that allowed for character development in a natural, unforced manner. It showed the trials and tribulations of Black women in the south while also showing their strength. A movie like this was an inevitability. Who would have the best gossip other than the servants who were around all of the time? And who had the most motivation to expose those secrets? Oh yeah, this movie was going to happen, it was just a matter of what form it would take.

"Oscar season", as it's typically referred to, is a period of time, usually beginning in late November, and ending in late January. This year, it starts early, with The Help.

"The Help" is based on the well-known novel by Kathryn Stockett, someone who I had never heard of before discovering this film and book. For the most part, when I hear about a film that I want to see, I try to read the book prior to viewing the movie, to enhance the whole experience. Usually I get bored, or stop mid-way through one of these said books, before I end up watching the movie.

But "The Help" grabbed me. Stockett kept me on a leash, dying to know what happened next, and I ended up finishing its 530 pages in a few sittings. And, I'm glad it did, because "The Help" is not only the best movie I've seen this summer, but it very well could be the best one I see all year.

The film centers on Aibileen, Skeeter and Minny (Davis, Stone and Spencer, respectively) three very different women in Mississippi, in the year 1962. Skeeter is returning from graduating college with a journalism degree, whose beloved childhood black maid Constantine has disappeared, and no one will tell her where she has gone. Aibileen is a maid who has raised 17 white children in her life. Her outspoken friend Minny has never been able to keep quiet, or, because of this, hold onto a job very long. Skeeter decides to write a tell-all book of interviews from the maids of Jackson, Mississippi, which, as you could imagine, was a very taboo thing in that time and place.

One of the reasons that this film succeeds is that not a single character is miscast. In the book, Stockett paints a vivid picture of each character, and the actors clearly got lost in the characters they were playing. Emma Stone is becoming a very important actress. I haven't seen her in a role that I didn't love her in. After getting her first notable role in 2009's Zombieland, and then livening and carrying the otherwise bland teen comedy Easy A, this is her first dramatic role, as Skeeter, one of the lead characters. While she sometimes blends into the background in this movie, she shines beautifully with the rest of the cast. She's definitely one to watch.

While Stone is great, this movie belongs to Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer. Davis's Aibileen is perfect. She has a silent sadness about her, a lot of pride, and a great sense of anger, while never raising her voice the whole film. She handles emotional scenes beautifully, reducing the audience to tears in more than one scene. She's a early in the year front-runner for Best Actress this Oscar season.

Spencer also does a beautiful job as Minny. Octavia Spencer was the original inspiration for the character of Minny, who voiced the character's section in the audio-book. She was clearly made to play this role. She does a lot more for this movie, than just adding comic relief, but she plays the comedic side the best. The "terrible awful" that her character does in the book, is made into the funniest thing in the whole movie.

The supporting cast is dead-on too. Bryce Dallas Howard (Ron's daughter) plays the town's snobby ringleader, Hilly. She's absolutely chilling, nailing the evil character. Her mother, played by Sissy Spacek is a hoot. The town's secretive lush, and Minny's boss, Celia, is played by newcomer Jessica Chastain, who wowed earlier this year in "The Tree of Life". She was completely like I envisioned her character in the book. There's not enough typing space in this review to describe how much I loved the rest of the supporting cast. Everyone was dead-on.

I was under the assumption that this would be yet another disappointing film of a book loved by many. The reason for this was the director and writer. I had never heard of this Tate Taylor, and because of that, I wasn't sure that I trusted him. He had a large part in making this movie all that it was. One of the big reasons that "The Help" works as a movie is because it feels authentic. It was filmed in Mississippi, where it's based, it is set in the 1960's, and every feeling about the movie hits the right note.

I later discovered that Taylor was a childhood friend of the book's author. Not some Hollywood hack. I forget the many disappointing film adaptations of books I loved that were made by the Hollywood elite. "The Da Vinci Code" by Ron Howard, "Memoirs of a Geisha" by Rob Marshall, "Eat, Pray, Love" by Ryan Murphy. Enough said. After seeing this film, I couldn't imagine anyone better-suited to making the film.

What is special about this film is that it is not what a lot of people will probably write it off as. It is not a film to make white audiences feel less white guilt. It avoids this sentimentality, I don't know how, but it succeeds in that, like I thought it wouldn't.

While some changes are (intelligently) made from the book, it's almost a scene-for-scene adaptation of the book. Some things are different, because they need to be, and things are a little more concise, yet it's almost like watching an abridged version of the book, on screen. I can't say enough good things about this film.
